MINUTES OF MEETING- OF THE ADULT EDUCATION COMMITTEE OF THE
NAEB HELD IN NEW YORK CITY TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1952
Members of the committee present were Probst, chairman, Hull, Siegel, and
Wheatley; by invitation, Harley and Miles; for luncheon only. Fuller and Papp.
(Hull did not arrive until 10:30 A.M.)
The meeting began at 9:30 A.M. Probst stated that there were four general
items on the agenda: (l) A report from Harley on the four areas of the pro¬
ject; (2) The question of Harley’s continuance in his present position after
June 1; (3) The decision on what to do in the public affairs program project
area with the development of the withdrawal by Las swell of his suggestion
for a Washington, D.C. program operation; and (a) A report of the recent meet¬
ing with the Fund for Adult Education in Pasadena.
Inasmuch as Hull had been present in Pasadena and was familiar with that area
of the agenda, Probst suggested that to economize on time the meeting begin
with item four—a review of the recent meeting with Mr. Scott Fletcher and
the staff of the FAE in Pasadena. Harley, Hull, Probst, and Wheatley had been
invited as individuals to come to Pasadena and consult with Fletcher and his
staff at the FAE on the problem of educational television. A number of other
people were also invited, among them President Arthur S. Adams of the American
Council on Education and Ralph Steetle. At all times 16 to 13 people were in
the meetings. More than half the time was spent discussing television. Ther^
was no place nor opportunity for a statement on NAEB needs for next year.
There were no promises made that there would be any grants; in general, however,
it can be said that Fletcher and his entire staff were very pleased with the
progress that had been made and that they were completely sold on the Adult
Education Project of the NAEB. They are impressed by the quality of the people
we have assembled to work on the Lowell project; for example, Mr. Fletcher is
very impressed by Professor Walter Goldschmidt, director of our Ways of Mankind
project. The only specific grant made by Mr. Fletcher to the NAEB was $3,000.00
for printing the Chicago and second New York monitoring studies. This money is
now on its way to Treasurer Schooley.
The views of Mr. Fletcher regarding publicity on the monitoring studies have
changed. Mr. Fletcher wants as wide a dissemination of the results of the
studies as can be made. In the discussion on this point, after the request
for $2,500.00 had been presented by Probst, an additional $500.00 was granted
by Mr. Fletcher to be used for promotional purposes. Mr. Fletcher asked who
was handling NAEB promotion. He wants a vigorous campaign to promote the studies
—but not a political fight type of promotion. Mr. Fletcher said he was not
impressed by the promotion and news coverage given to the Los Angeles study,
and that the FAE wants wider dissemination of the information collected. They
would like to see articles appear in the Readers Digest, etc. Siegel stated
that he believed Fletcher should be pleased with the promotion and news cover¬
age that was given to the Los Angeles study. Probst said that the matter of
promotion was the NAEB’s responsibility—that the Adult Education Committee was
no longer the Committee to Supervise the Monitoring Studies, and the promotion
problem continued to be Siegel’s responsibility. Siegel said that it would be
easy to work up a big campaign on the studies, but that the optimum time for
publicity was past—that the studies were getting old.
